thread.section_title: Primark issue urgent recall over fears that children’s leggings may be deadly – Metro
thread.title: Primark issue urgent recall over fears that children’s leggings may be deadly
thread.title_full: Primark issue urgent recall over fears that children’s leggings may be deadly

author: georgiadiebelius1
title: Primark issue urgent recall over fears that children’s leggings may be deadly
text:
The leggings are being recalled (Picture: Primark) Primark have issued an urgent recall over a pair of children’s leggings over fears they may be deadly.
The high street store are asking customers to return the novelty cat clothing as the bows on the knee area present a potential choking hazard.
Girl, 15, sexually assaulted by 6 men on Facebook Live - but nobody reported to police All leggings with the product number 86503 are being recalled.
The ‘dangerous’ leggings were sold across the UK between November 8 and February 22.
A spokesperson added that the clothing can be returned for a full refund without proof of purchase.
Primark are offering a full refund (Picture: Nick Ansell/PA Wire) They said: ‘Through our ongoing due-diligence programme it has come to our attention that the Novelty Cat Legging detailed above does not meet the Primark usual high standards for safety.
‘We have found a potential issue with the security of the bow attachment within the product that may become detached and present a potential choking hazard.
Contraceptive pill can protect from some types of cancer ‘With the safety of our customers at the forefront of our minds we are inviting you to return this item for a full refund.
‘If you have purchased this product then please return it to any Primark store where you will be offered a full refund. You will not be required to provide proof of purchase.’
Last month, Co-Op issued an urgent recall after a three-year-old girl found a deadly battery inside her chocolate bunny.
Tammy-Louise Dundon, 26, bought the bunny for her daughter Sophia from a supermarket in in Nottingham.
However she was horrified when the three-year-old bit off the chocolate ears and discovered a single-cell battery ‘rattling around’.
